entry.string:
from CoreGraphics import * # how to load and display and image in Field
# here we load something out of the sheet data folder (which is just a folder inside the .field 'package' that this document is saves in
anImage = image(_self.sheetDataFolder+"bricks.jpg")
# to put it on screen we'd just write #anImage.show()
# but it's a bit big, so we'll scale it down first:
anImage *= Vector2(0.2, 0.2)
# before 'showing' this image we clear all the lines that this box is drawing, otherwise every time we run the code in this box we end up adding an additional image on top of all the previous ones _self.lines.clear() anImage.show( (50, 50) )

baseTool( node=Direct(0, 0, "n"), coords=(Rel(None, Vector2(49.0, 491.0), None), ) )
baseTool( node=Direct(1, 0, "n"), coords=(Rel(None, Vector2(44.0, 711.0), None), ) )
baseTool( node=Direct(2, 0, "n"), coords=(Rel(None, Vector2(404.0, 487.0), None), ) )
baseTool( node=Direct(3, 0, "n"), coords=(Rel(None, Vector2(393.0, 711.0), None), ) )

_self.lines.clear()
# if you run the box above us first, that will load an image called 'anImage' we'll modify in here
# first, a very simple blur
blurredImage = anImage << blur(10)
# and let's shrink it down again blurredImage *= Vector2(0.5, 0.5) blurredImage.show( decor= 0 )
# blured is just a shorthand for this
blurredImage2 = anImage << filter("CIGaussianBlur", inputRadius=10) #blurredImage2 = anImage << filter("CIColorPosterize", inputRadius=10) blurredImage2 *= Vector2(0.5, 0.5) # since this is the exact same thing, there's no point putting on the screen #blurredImage2.show( decor= 0 )
# Apple ships a lot of default filters with their OS (google Core Image Reference for a list) filteredImage = anImage << filter("CIMotionBlur", inputRadius=20, inputAngle=50) << filter("CISharpenLuminance", inputSharpness=20.0) filteredImage *= Vector2(0.5, 0.5) filteredImage.show( decor=0 )
# you'll note that Field / Core Image does the "right thing" when images grow outside their bounds filteredImage = anImage for n in range(0, 4): filteredImage <<= filter("CIBumpDistortion", inputCenter=Vector2(200,200).noise(300), inputScale=1)
filteredImage *= Vector2(0.25, 0.25) filteredImage.show( decor=0 )
# but you are not limited to the built in functions myFilter = customFilter("""
kernel vec4 redScaler(sampler inputImage, float redScale) { return sample(inputImage, samplerCoord(inputImage)*vec2(2,1))*vec4(redScale,1,1,1); }
""", [ "inputImage", "redScale" ])
# Apple uses a language which is a lot like GLSLang (and Adobe Pixel Blender and so on...) to write these super fast, GPU accelerated image transforms. The one we wrote above scales the red channel by a parameter and compressed the image along the x axis
redImage = anImage << myFilter(redScale=3.2) redImage *= Vector2(0.5, 0.5) redImage.show (decor =0 )
# (note: instead of positioning the images in code, I'm just using mouse-basde editing to drag them around) _self.tweaks()

# you are not limited to loading images off of disk, you can originate them yourself
imageData = makeFloatImageData(256, 256) for y in range(0, 256): for x in range(0, 256): imageData.put(x/256.0) #red imageData.put(y/256.0) #green imageData.put(0.0) #blue imageData.put(1.0) #alpha
ii = image(imageData, 256, 256)
_self.lines.clear() ii.show(decor=0)
_self.tweaks()

# the other way to originate image data is to rasterize PLine sets
_self.lines.clear()
ll = PLine().moveTo(0,0).polarCubicTo(1,1,-1,-1,200,100).polarCubicTo(-1,-1,1,1,100,200) ll+= Vector2(1000, 500) for n in range(0, 10): ll = ll.copy() ll += rotation(0.4*Math.random()) ll(color=Color4(0,0,0,0.7/(n+1)), derived=1) _self.lines.add(ll)
# here's a drop shadow rasterImage = rasterizeLines()
# after the call to rasterizeLines we have an image object that we can filter rasterImage <<= blur(5) rasterImage.defaultPosition.x+=3 rasterImage.defaultPosition.y+=5 rasterImage.show(decor=0) rasterImage <<= blur(5) rasterImage.defaultPosition.x+=3 rasterImage.defaultPosition.y+=5 rasterImage.show(decor=0)
